In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the function in Julia:

```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    if typeof(dt) == DateTime
        return dt + Hour(bump)
    elseif typeof(dt) == Date
        error("Input must be a DateTime type, not a Date type.")
    else
        error("Invalid input type. Please provide a DateTime or Date object.")
    end
end
```

This function takes a `DateTime` as an argument and returns the same time shifted by `bump` hours. If you pass in a `Date`, it will throw an error. It also checks if the input is of type `DateTime` or `Date`. If not, it throws an error indicating that only DateTime or Date objects are accepted.
